questions.text: The septum pellucidum separates the following structures_______?

choices.text: Anterior horns of the lateral ventricles
Posterior horns of the lateral ventricles
Inferior horns of the lateral ventricles

questions.solution:
The septum pellucidum(1.5-3.0 mm thin) is a thin two layered transparent membrane that separates the anterior horns of the lateral ventricles.

It extends from the anterior portion of the corpus callosum to the fornix.

Relations

  • Superiorly: body of corpus callosum
  • Inferiorly: rostrum of corpus callosum
  • Anteriorly: genu of corpus callosum
  • Posteriorly: third ventricle
  • Laterally: anterior horns and body of lateral ventricles

Clinical Significance - Absence of the septum pellucidum is often associated with conditions such as septo-optic dysplasia, a rare developmental disorder showing abnormal development of the optic disk and pituitary defects.

Above image makings:

  1. Corpus callosum, Rostrum
  2. Corpus callosum, Genu
  3. Corpus callosum, Corpus
  4. Corpus callosum, Splenium
  5. Septum pellucidum
  6. Fornix, Corpus

questions.text: Classified according to its blood supply, what type of muscle is Rectus Abdominis.
questions.solution:
Rectus Abdominis is a Type III muscle, as it is supplied by two separate dominant pedicles, each from different source arteries, the superior and inferior epigastric arteries.

The gross vascular anatomy of muscles has been classified into five types according to the number and relative dominance of vascular pedicles that enter the muscle.

Type Blood Supply by Examples
Type I A single vascular pedicle supplying the muscle belly Tensor fasciae latae, Gastrocnemius
Type II A single dominant vascular pedicle and several minor pedicles Gracilis
Type III Two separate dominant pedicles, from different source arteries. Rectus abdominis, Gluteus maximus
Type IV Multiple small pedicles that, are not capable of supporting the muscle individually Sartorius and Tibialis anterior
Type V One dominant vascular pedicle and multiple secondary segmental pedicles Latissimus Dorsi

questions.text: All of the following are retinal glial cells, except?
questions.solution:
Amacrine cells are the intrinsic inhibitory neurons, which interacting with retinal ganglion cells and/or bipolar cells.

There are three types of retinal glial cells:

  • Müller cells - predominant glial element of the retina
  • Astrocytes - are largely confined to the ganglion cell and nerve fibre layers
  • Microglia - scattered throughout the neural part of the retina in small numbers

questions.text: Which of the following structures projects into the Right Atrium and is responsible for the Torus Aorticus?
questions.solution:
Torus aorticus or aortic mound is the prominent projection of the non-coronary (right posterior) aortic sinus into the right atrial septum.

The bulge is superior to the coronary sinus and anterior to the fossa ovalis.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior (‘right coronary’) aortic sinus; The left coronary artery arises from the left posterior (left coronary) aortic sinus.

questions.text: The greater splanchnic nerve is formed by the following thoracic ganglia
questions.solution:
The greater splanchnic nerve is formed by branches from the fifth to ninth or tenth thoracic ganglia and consists mainly of myelinated preganglionic efferent and visceral afferent fibers.

It descends obliquely on the vertebral bodies, supplies branches to the descending thoracic aorta, and perforates the ipsilateral diaphragmatic crus to end mainly in the coeliac ganglion.

The lesser splanchnic nerve is formed by rami of the ninth and tenth (sometimes the tenth and eleventh) thoracic ganglia.

questions.text: The Nerve of Kuntz should be identified in?
questions.solution:
The failure to identify the Nerve of Kuntz during thoracic sympathectomy for hyperhidrosis may result in failure of treatment.

It is an inconstant intrathoracic ramus which carries sympathetic fibres to the brachial plexus without passing through the sympathetic trunk. It joins the 2nd intercostal nerve to the ventral ramus of the 1st thoracic nerve, proximal to the point where the latter joins gives a branch to the brachial plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the perirenal fascia___?

choices.text: Paranephric space lies posterior to the fascia
Inferiorly, the perirenal fascia envelops the superior mesentric vessels
It separates the adipose capsule from the pararenal fat

questions.solution:
The perirenal fascia does not envelop the superior mesentric vessels. It extends downwards to enclose the ureters.

The peripancreatic space contains the superior mesenteric vessels along with duodenum and pancreas.

The perirenal fascia is a multilaminated structure that passes behind the kidneys and divides into posterior fascia of Zuckerkandl and the anterior fascia of Gerota.

Posterior to this lies the posterior paranephric space which does not contain any abdominal organs.

questions.text: Brachialis is innervated by the following nerve roots
questions.solution: The Brachialis is innervated by C5,C6 & C7. The musculocutaneous nerve (C5 and 6) supplies a large medial part of the muscle, and the radial nerve (C7) supplies a small lateral part.

questions.text: Which type of ossification are the bones of the Skull Base formed by?
questions.solution: The bones of the skull base are formed by endochondral ossification (chondrocranium), whereas those of the calvaria and face ossify directly from mesenchymal condensations, i.e. by intramembranous ossification.

questions.text: All the following muscles are supplied by the branches of the facial artery except?
questions.solution:
The Styloglossus is supplied only by the sublingual branch of the lingual artery.

Hyoglossus, Chondroglossus and Genioglossus are supplied by both the submental branch of the facial artery and the sublingual branch of the lingual artery.

The ascending palatine artery, which is one of the cervical branches of the facial artery supplies the Palatoglossus along with greater palatine artery, a terminal branch of the descending palatine artery from the third part of the maxillary artery.

questions.text: All the following are derivatives of Mesencephalon except?
questions.solution:
Thalamus is derived from Diencephalon of the forebrain.

Cerebral peduncles, Tegmentum, Aqueduct and Tectum are derivatives of Mesencephalon or Midbrain.

Related Pearl: Divisions of the Developing Brain

Divisions of the Developing Brain
Forebrain vesicle/Prosencephalon

Telencephalon

  • Cerebral cortex
  • Subcortical white matter
  • Amygdala
  • Basal ganglia
  • Hippocampus
  • Olfactory bulb and tract
  • Cavities: Lateral ventricles

Diencephalon

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus
  • Epithalamus
  • Subthalamus
  • Optic nerve and retina
  • Cavities: 3rd ventricle
Midbrain vesicle/Mesencephalon

Mesencephalon

  • Midbrain
  • Cavities: Cerebral Aqueduct

Hindbrain vesicle/Rhombencephalon

Metencephalon

  • Pons
  • Cerebellum 

Myelencephalon

  • Medulla oblongata

Common Cavity: 4th Ventricle

questions.text: Growth curve of which of the following tissues peaks at around 12 years of age?
questions.solution: Note that the growth of lymphoid tissue, thymus, lymph nodes and intestinal lymph masses peaks at puberty then decreases afterwards.

questions.text: Which is the correct order for the movement of sperm?

choices.text: Seminiferous Tubule -> Efferent Tubules -> Rete Tubules
Efferent Tubule -> Rete Testis -> Seminiferous Tubules

questions.solution: The pathway of the sperm proceeds from Seminiferous tubules -> Rete testis -> Efferent tubules.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the axillary artery except?

choices.text: It is crossed by a part of pectoralis major muscle
It is a continuation of subclavian artery
The second part of part of axillary artery is posterior to pectoralis minor muscle
It extends from outer border of first rib to the lower border of teres major

questions.solution:
It is crossed by the pectoralis minor muscle and is divided into three parts.

  • First part - superior to the muscle
  • Second part - posterior to the muscle
  • Third part - inferior to the muscle

questions.text: Which of the given statements is not false regarding the lateral geniculate body?

choices.text: It is connected to the inferior colliculus
It is situated posterolateral to the medial geniculate body
It is overlapped by the lateral part of the temporal lobe
Layers 1, 4 and 6 receive the contralateral optic fibers

questions.solution:
Layers 1, 4 and 6 receive the contralateral optic fibers.

The Lateral geniculate body is connected to the superior colliculus. It is situated anterolateral to the medial geniculate body and is overlapped by the medial part of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: All the following are of a General somatic afferent type except?

choices.text: Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal Nerve
Mandibular division of the trigeminal Nerve

questions.solution:
The Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) is a special visceral efferent.

Note : there is disagreement regarding the terminology,  some investigators believe the spinal accessory must carry special visceral efferent (SVE) information, Continuity with nucleus ambiguus of the medulla also supports this view. Others, consider the spinal accessory nerve to carry general somatic efferent (GSE) information. Still others believe it is reasonable to conclude that the spinal accessory nerve contains both SVE and GSE components 

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 2,8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

questions.text: The cell membrane predominantly consists of the greatest mass ratio of  ______
questions.solution:
The amount of proteins equals the quantity of lipid in nearly all membranes.

Various cellular membranes have different lipid and protein compositions.

The cell membrane consists of lipid molecules (which predominantly includes phospholipids) that constitute the basic framework of the membrane.

Most plasma membranes consist of approximately 50% lipid and 50% protein by weight, with the carbohydrate portions of glycolipids and glycoproteins constituting 5 to 10% of the membrane mass.

But considering the fact that proteins are much larger than lipids, this percentage corresponds to about one protein molecule per every 50 to 100 molecules of lipid, cell membrane’s predominantly consists of phospholipids, which means the proteins have a higher mass ratio than the lipids.

The trilaminar structure of membranes is produced by the arrangement of lipid molecules. Each phospholipid molecule consists of an enlarged head with a phosphate portion and two thin tails.

questions.text: The transverse ligament of atlas is a part of ______
questions.solution:
The transverse ligament of atlas and longitudinal components together constitute the cruciform ligament.

The transverse ligament of atlas is a strong band that arches across the atlantal ring and is attached laterally to a small but prominent tubercle on the medial side of each atlantal lateral mass.

From its upper margin, a strong median longitudinal band arises that inserts into the basilar part of the occipital bone and from its inferior surface a weaker and less consistent longitudinal band passes to the posterior surface of the axis.

These transverse and longitudinal components together constitute the cruciform ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is an example of diarthric muscle?
questions.solution:
The muscles that extend over two joints are called diarthric muscles. E.g. Hamstrings.

The muscles that extend over more than two joints are called polyarthric muscles. E.g. flexor digitorum profundus.

questions.text: Find the wrong statement in relation to Meckel’s diverticulum.

choices.text: It is a congenital diverticulum arising from mesenteric border of ileum
It is seen in 2-3% of individuals
All three layers of the bowel wall are present
Inflammation of Meckel’s diverticulum mimics appendicitis

questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum arising from anti-mesenteric border of ileum.

Since it is a true diverticulum, all 3 layers of the bowel wall (Mucosa, Submucosa and Muscularis propria) are present.

As it is a remnant of the proximal part of vitelline duct, which is made up of pluripotent cell lining, Meckel's diverticulum may harbour abnormal tissues, containing embryonic remnants of other tissue types, mostly gastric mucosa.

Diverticular inflammation may mimic acute appendicitis; since Meckel’s diverticulum and the appendix are both derived from midgut structures, pain is referred to the periumbilical region.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is regarding interstitial cells of Cajal is incorrect?

choices.text: They are seen throughout the gastro intestinal tract
They are involved in generation of pacemaker signals related to GI motility

questions.solution:
Interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC) are considered specialized smooth muscle cells.

  • They are found throughout the entire length of the gastrointestinal tract, where they lie in close contact with nerve terminals.
  • They originate from mesenchymal cells and networks are found in the myenteric plexus between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers.
  • They lie in contact with each other and neighbouring smooth muscle cells via gap junctions.
  • Actively involved in the generation of pacemaker signals, the propagation of electrical slow wave activity, neuromuscular transmission, and mechanosensation.

Isolated or small groups of ICCs are also found in connective tissue septa and the subserosal region.

Defective ICC function has been implicated in a wide range of intestinal motility disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the colon are retroperitoneal?

choices.text: Caecum, sigmoid colon and splenic flexure
Ascending colon, descending colon and rectum
Entire colon except splenic and hepatic flexures

questions.solution:
The Ascending colon, descending colon and rectum are retroperitoneal structures.

Parts with Mesentery Transverse colon, Sigmoid colon, Appendix, Cecum
Retroperitoneal parts Ascending and descending colon and upper 1/3rd of rectum
Parts devoid of peritoneal coverings Anal canal, Lower 1/3rd of rectum

questions.text: The large intestine is made up of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The large intestine is derived from midgut, hindgut and proctoduem.

Embryological Structure Derivatives Blood Supply
Foregut

Pharynx

Esophaus

Stomach

Proximal duodenum (till ampula of Vater)

 Coeliac Trunk
Midgut

Distal part of duodenum

Jejunum

Ileum

Caecum

Appendix

Ascending colon

Right 2/3rd of transverse colon

 Superior mesenteric artery
Hindgut

Distal 1/3rd of transverse colon

Descending colon

Sigmoid colon

Rectum

Upper part of anal canal

 Inferior mesenteric artery
Proctodeum Lower part of anal canal(below pectinate line) Middle and inferior rectal artery

questions.text: Which of the following are the supports of the liver?
questions.solution:
The liver is supported by all of the above mentioned options.

Supports of the liver:

The liver is stabilized and maintained in its position in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen by both static and dynamic factors: 

Factors Support provided by
Primary factors Suspensory attachments at the posterior abdominal wall to the inferior vena cava, hepatic veins, coronary and triangular ligaments
Secondary factors The right kidney, right colic flexure and duodenopancreatic complex. 
Tertiary factors The attachment to the anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm by the falciform ligament.

 Other factors which support the liver include, positive intra-abdominal pressure and the movement of the diaphragm during respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following fissures are visible on the surface of the liver

choices.text: Umbilical fissure, Venous fissures, and fissure of Gans
Left portal fissure, right portal fissure and the main fissure
Rouviere’s sulcus, fissure of Gans and left portal fissure
Median portal fissure, right portal fissure and the main fissure

questions.solution:
The three minor fissures (umbilical, venous and fissure of Gans) are visible as physical clefts of the liver surface. The fissure of Gans is also known as Rouvière’s sulcus or the incisura hepatis dextra. Accessory fissures are rare.

Three major fissures are the main, left and right portal fissures not visible on the surface, run through the liver parenchyma and contain the three main hepatic veins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of levator ani muscle?
questions.solution:
Ischiococcygeus also called coccygeus is a separate muscle.

The remaining three pubococcygeus, ileococcygeus and puborectalis  together are referred to as levator ani.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles help with the internal rotation of the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
Subscapularis helps with the internal rotation of the shoulder. Other muscles causing internal rotation are – Pectoralis Major, Teres Major and Latissimus Dorsi.

Teres Minor helps with external rotation along with Infraspinatus and posterior deltoid.

Coracobrachialis helps with flexion of the elbow and vertical adduction of the arm.

questions.text: The Suspensory ligament of the penis is formed by?
questions.solution: The deep membranous fascia of the abdomen called the Scarpa’s fascia continues in the midline, thickens and forms the suspensory ligament of the penis or clitoris.

questions.text: All the following are attached to Whitnall’s tubercle except?
questions.solution:
The Whitnall’s ligament (also called superior transverse ligament of the eye) does not attach to the Whitnall’s tubercle.

It attaches laterally to the lacrimal gland above the Whitnall tubercle and medially to the pulley of superior oblique muscle.

The structures that attach to the whitnall’s tubercle are:

  • Lockwood suspensory ligament
  • Lateral rectus check ligament
  • Lateral palpebral ligament
  • Levator palpebrae superioris aponeurosis

questions.text: All the following structures pass through superior orbital foramen except?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmic arteries pass through the Optic Canal.

The following structures pass through the superior orbital foramen:

  • CN III, CN IV, CN V1, CN VI,
  • Superior orbital vein
  • Branch of middle meningeal artery

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: Caudate lobe of the liver comprises
questions.solution:
Segment I corresponds to the anatomical caudate lobe and lies posterior to segment IV, with its left half directly adjacent to segment II and its medial half wrapped around the retrohepatic segment of the inferior vena cava to a variable extent.

Sometimes, it is subdivided into three parts : caudate process, Spiegel lobe and paracaval portion.

questions.text: What is the second bone to ossify in the human body?
questions.solution:
The mandible is the second bone to ossify in the human body. The primary ossification center appears by the 7th week of Intrauterine life.

Part of the mandible between mental and mandibular foramina ossifies in membrane from mesenchymal sheath of Meckel’s cartilage (first arch cartilage).

Part of the mandible medial to mental foramen ossifies directly from Meckel’s cartilage (endochondral ossification).

Note: Clavicle is the first bone to ossify.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not form the border of Hepatobiliary triangle?
questions.solution:
The triangular region formed between the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct and the inferior surface of the liver is the hepatobiliary triangle.

Hepatobiliary and calot's triangles are often confused with each other. 

Hepatobiliary triangle

  • cystic duct,
  • common hepatic duct
  • inferior surface of the liver

Calot’s triangle

  • common hepatic duct,
  • cystic artery
  • cystic duct 

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the cystic artery Inferior surface of the liver

Medially

 Common hepatic duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: ______ is the homolog of prostate in females
questions.solution: Paraurethral glands or Skene’s glands are the homologs of prostate in women. The secretions of these glands form the female ejaculate.

questions.text: Regarding urinary continence in the male which one of the following statements is not correct?

choices.text: The internal urethral sphincter represents the point of highest urethral pressure
The external urethral sphincter is striated muscle fibres of slow twitching type
The Onuf’s nucleus in S2,3&4 segments of spinal cord controls external urethral sphincter
Onuf’s nucleus is under the inhibitory control of pons

questions.solution:
The external urethral sphincter represents the point of highest intraurethral pressure in the normal, contracted, state.

They are innervated by neurons that lie in Onuf’s nucleus in fourth sacral spinal segments.

Pons firing causes central activation of Onuf’s nucleus to increase the tone of the external sphincter > holding of urine, Vice versa central inhibition of Onuf’s nucleus causes > voiding of urine. 

The slow-twitch fibres of the external sphincter are capable of sustained contraction over relatively long periods of time and actively contribute to the tone that closes the urethra and maintains urinary continence.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the pilosebaceous unit

choices.text: Pilosebaceous units develop in a cranio–caudal direction at about 9 weeks gestation

questions.solution:
Pilosebaceous units develop in a craniocaudal direction at 9 weeks’ gestation, first in the regions of the eyebrows, lips and chin.

Hairs produced prenatally are called lanugo hairs, which are short and downy, lack a medulla, and in certain parts of the body are arranged in a vortex-like manner into tracts.

Late in pregnancy, lanugo hairs are replaced by vellus hairs, and these in turn by intermediate hairs, which are the predominant type until puberty.

New follicles do not develop in postnatal skin.

questions.text: The remnants of Mullerian duct in males are
questions.solution:
Hydatids Of Morgagni and the Prostatic utricule in the floor of prostatic urethra are the remnants of Müllerian duct in males.

The Müllerian ducts are the primordial analog of the female reproductive tract. They differentiate to form the fallopian tubes, uterus, the uterine cervix, and the superior aspect of the vagina.

The development of these paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts is controlled by the presence or absence of Anti Müllerian hormone(AMH) or Müllerian inhibiting hormone.

In males, the developing testes produce AMH causing regression of the paramesonephric ducts.

When the hydatid morgagni undergoes torsion it presents with features similar to torsion of testis.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Kidney in a newborn shows 12 lobulations
In horseshoe kidney the ureters pass posterior to the isthmus
The lower border of the kidney is at L3 vertebrae
The left kidney lies close to the median plane than the right

questions.solution:
In horseshoe kidney the ureters usually pass anterior to the isthmus.

 

Superiorly, they are level with the upper border of the T12 vertebra, and inferiorly, with the L3 vertebra.

The right is usually slightly inferior to the left and the left is a little longer and narrower than the right and lies nearer the median plane.

In the fetus and the newborn, the kidney normally has 12 lobules; in the adult, these lobules fuse to present a smooth surface, although traces of lobulation may remain and can mimic a renal mass.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The narrowest part of the tube is the intramural part
The lateral part of the tube is supplied by ovarian artery while the medial by uterine artery
Typically fertilisation takes place in the ampulla
The ovarian lymphatics drain into the internal iliac nodes and lymphatics from the body of the uterus into the para-aortic nodes

questions.solution:
The main lymphatic drainage of the ovaries is along vessels that follow the ovarian veins to para-aortic nodes situated near the origin of the renal arteries.

Vessels from the body of the uterus and cervix pass laterally in the parametrium to three main groups of lymph nodes: the external and internal iliac and the obturator nodes.

Structure Lymph nodes
Vulva Labia, clitoris and perineum Superficial inguinal
Perineum and lower labia majora Rectal lymphatic plexus
Clitoris Superficial inguinal, deep inguinal and internal iliac.
Vagina Upper vagina Internal and external iliac
Middle vagina Internal iliac
Lower vagina Superficial inguinal
Uterus Fundus Para-aortic
Isthmus and round ligament Superficial inguinal
Body, including cervix Internal and external iliac and obturator
Fallopian tubes Fallopian tubes Para-aortic, internal iliac, superficial inguinal
Ovaries Ovaries Para-aortic

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do the delta basophils of the hypophysis cerebri secrete?
questions.solution:
The gonadotrophs (delta basophils) produce two types of hormones, follicle stimulating hormone, and luteinizing hormone.

The following types of cells have been described in the pituitary:

Acidophil Cells:

  • Somatotrophs: secretes somatotropin, or growth hormone
  • Mammotropes (or lactotropes): produce Prolactin, Lactogenic hormones

Basophil Cells:

  • Corticotropes : Secretes ACTH
  • Thyrotropes : Secretes TSH
  • Gonadotrophs : Secretes FSH and LH

questions.text: Identify the staining method used in the electron microscopic image given below.
questions.solution:
The staining method given in the image is osmium staining.

Osmium tetraoxide is used to stain lipids in electron micoscopy.

It dissolves in fats, and is reduced by organic materials to elemental osmium, an easily visible black substance. Osmium is a heavy metal and electron-dense. It will appear opaque and can be visualized in electron microscopy.

 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: The diameter of the Terminal arterioles ranges between _______
questions.solution:
A1 – Arterioles <50 μm in diameter are called terminal arterioles, the smallest terminal arterioles having a diameter as small as 12 μm.

The muscular arteries progressively decrease in calibre till they have a diameter of about 100 μm.

They then become continuous with arterioles. The larger or muscular arterioles are 100 to 50 μm in diameter.

questions.text: The upper end of the femur is ossified from ______ ossification centers.
questions.solution:
There are three ossification center for the upper (proximal) end of the femur.

There are total 5 ossification centers of the femur, which include:

  • One (primary) for the shaft of the femur
  • Three (secondary) for the proximal end of the femur, one each for head, greater and lesser trochanters
  • One (secondary) for the distal end of the femur

questions.text: Schmidt–Lanterman incisures are seen in which of the following structures
questions.solution:
Schmidt–Lanterman incisures are found in are helical decompactions of internodal myelin seen in glial cells (Schwann cells), where the major dense line of the myelin sheath) splits to enclose a spiral of oligodendrocyte cytoplasm.

They are histological evidence of the small amount of cytoplasm that remains in the inner layer of the myelin sheath created by Schwann cells wrapping tightly around an axon.

questions.text: Ameloblasts develop from
questions.solution:
Ameloblasts develop from the surface ectoderm. They are present during tooth development and deposit enamel.

The ameloblasts become fully functional following the formation of the first layer of dentin (predentin) by odontoblasts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the glycoprotein Tenascin?

choices.text: Tenascin is abundant in embryonic tissues but is restricted in the adult
It inhibits axonal growth and migration of cells
It is a small glycoprotein composed of 2 subunits
It promotes cell migration and axonal growth

questions.solution:
Tenascin is large glycoprotein composed of six subunits that are joined at one end to form a structure that resembles the spokes of a wheel.

Tenascin is abundant in embryonic tissues but its distribution is restricted in the adult.

It appears to be important in guiding cell migration and axonal growth in early development: it may either promote or inhibit these activities, depending on the cell type and tenascin isoform.

questions.text: The superior gemellus muscle is supplied by all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
The medial circumflex femoral artery supplies inferior gemellus muscle, not the superior.

The gemelli are two narrow and triangular muscles, in the gluteal region. They are separated by the obturator internus tendon.

Arterial supply:

  • Gemellus superior - by the internal pudendal artery, the inferior gluteal artery; and sometimes by the superior gluteal artery.
  • Gemellus inferior - by the medial circumflex femoral artery.

questions.text: Sibson’s fascia attaches at _____ vertebra?
questions.solution:
It is attached to the transverse process of the C7 vertebrae.

The suprapleural membrane (Sibson’s fascia) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax.

It is attached:

  • Anteriorly to the inner border of the first rib
  • Posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra

It is covered and strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibres derived from the scaleni.

questions.text: Which of the following is the venous drainage of external hemorrhoids?

choices.text: Portal system via internal pudendal vein
Portal system via superior rectal vein

questions.solution:
External hemorrhoids drain via the inferior rectal vein which drain into the internal pudendal vein. which further drains into the internal iliac vein finally into the IVC.

Internal hemorrhoids are drained by the superior rectal vein to the inferior mesenteric vein and into the hepatic portal vein

questions.text: The histological section of a nerve fibre is given. Which of the following indicates the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Endoneurium (Henle's sheath) is a layer of delicate connective tissue around the myelin sheath of each myelinated nerve fiber.

Within the nerve, axons targeting the same anatomical location are bundled together into groups known as fascicles, each surrounded by another protective sheath known as the perineurium.

Several fascicles may be in turn bundled together with a blood supply and fatty tissue within yet another sheath, the epineurium.
